project.name: undertakers
project.description: The Developer Relations Undertakers project handles developer retirement, both when developers announce their retirement as well as due to developer inactivity.

longdescription.p: The Developer Relations Undertakers project handles developer retirement, both when developers announce their retirement as well as due to developer inactivity.

ul.li:
Check cvs and bugzilla activity
An easy way to check cvs activity is by using the command "cvs history -c -u devname | sort | less" which displays devname's activity across all cvs repositories. We also have monthly cvs slacker mails mailed to devrel@gentoo.org on the 1st of every month and http://www.gentoo.org/proj/en/devrel/undertakers/scripts contains various homegrown scripts as well that mostly needs to be run from cvs.gentoo.org.
Check http://bugday.gentoo.org/bugsgoactivity.php?id=devname to see the last few bugzilla activities. Activity is defined very broadly in this case so commenting, changing resolution, cc'ing etc. all count as activity. You need to look at each of those bugs to decide if the activity is related to development.

Try talking to leads if the developer looks inactive - the developer might be active in ways we can't determine easily but is still useful to Gentoo. Ping the developer on irc, sent him/her an email etc. You don't have to do all of this but make a reasonable effort to make sure the developer is indeed inactive before starting the retirement process.

File a retirement bug. If the developer already has a "New Dev" bug convert that to a retirement bug. Retirement bugs should be in the Developer Relations product and assigned to devrel@gentoo.org with the developer cc'ed. State on the bug last commit and bugs activity if applicable. Also state any appropriate input you may have gotten from leads.
Make sure the developer is cc'ed on the bug.
Wait at minimum two weeks to give the developer adequate time to respond on the bug. Often 3 or even 4 weeks are more appropriate.
Consider any responses carefully. We're supposed to help Gentoo (in this case by keeping the developer base "clean"), not to retire as many developers as possible.
Close bug if developer is considered active.
If the developer doesn't respond in the time given or is otherwise still considered inactive cc infra-bugs@gentoo.org on the bug and add a comment asking infrastructure to retire the developer.
CC infra per their retirement process and wait for them to report it as complete.
Remove access to #gentoo-dev (access is either removed completely or changed to voice depending or whether they ask for it or they're still considered active and helpful in the channel).
Ask a freenode staffer to remove any gentoo cloak.
Update userinfo.xml with new status (ldap is done automatically by infrastructures script).
Clean up metadata.xml's in the portage tree (easiest done using the retire.py script by marienz available at http://www.gentoo.org/proj/en/devrel/undertakers/scripts/retire.py.txt).
